section.title: Written Assignments
section.p: As the term progresses, more written assignments will be added to the list here. These must be turned in no later than their posted due dates. Written assignments are each worth 1 of your final grade, and there will be ten in total. That means they are worth 10 in total, so you cannot expect to pass this course with an A unless you are turning these assignments in. These are where you will get to show me your mathematical writing skills and work on your ability to create a convincing logical argument.

The most important thing to understand about your written homework is that you are not merely finding and giving answers. You are explaining to someone what the problem was, how you handled it, and summarizing the results. In general, your write-ups should respect these five C's:
Clarity. Am I able to read your work? Is your writing legible? Have you written complete sentences that make sense, where appropriate? If you have charts, graphs, and mathematical expressions, have you clearly indicated what they represent? Generally, any graphs need their axes labeled with regularly spaced tick marks, and they need some kind of overall title. If something about your write-up causes me to pause and wonder what you mean, you will lose clarity points.
Correctness. Are your numerical answers and conclusions accurate? Often you can check that your numbers are correct by substituting numbers back into earlier equations. Also, by asking yourself if the numbers that you find make sense in the context of the problem. It's not a bad idea to include these checks with your work.
Conciseness. Have you rambled on with extra content that is not relevant to solving the problem? This is distracting and hurts the overall ability of your write-up to communicate effectively.
self-Containment. The response to the question that you submit should make it clear what the original question was. Put yourself in the shoes of another student from the class who does not have the original homework assignment in front of them. Would they be able to understand what you are talking about? At a minimum, this means that you must give an introduction of some kind that lets your reader know what you are about to investigate. Also, include any and all charts, graphs, and mathematical expressions that were given in the problem, and explain their meaning, even if you do so merely with labels.
Conclusions. Some problems come with context (word problems). When writing your final answer to such a question, you need to put that answer in its full context with a conclusion statement that is a complete English sentence. As an example, writing x=70 or He needs 70 will not be good enough if there is more context to the problem. Instead, something like Dmitri needs 70 in order to purchase a new lawnmower is a conclusion statement with all of the context in it. For problems without context, conclusion statements like So the domain of f is [0,\infty). are acceptable.

li.title: Written HW 1
li.p: Due Tuesday Oct 3

Demonstrate step by step how to calculate the value of \frac{\left\lvert4^2-34\right\rvert-2\sqrt{1+2(3)(8)}}{5^2-4\div2(11)}+\frac{7}{5}. Only make one simplification at a time, and leave a brief comment why you are making that particular simplification. For exmaple, the first simplification you might make is acting on the 4^2, because that is inside the absolute value bar grouping symbols, and exponentiation has the highest priority within htat group. Done right, there are over a dozen steps to calculating this value.

li.title: Written HW 2
li.p: Due Tuesday Oct 10

The school book store purchases textbooks at a wholesale price, and then assigns a shelf price by dividing the wholesale price by 0.77. The shelf price for a new basic algebra textbook is \$117.10. What was the wholesale price?

Do not respond to this question by simply doing a quick calculation and stating the result. Use the context description to set up a (simple) equation in one variable, whose solution will answer the question. Then do the step(s) to solve that equation. And then communicate the result in regular English.

li.title: Written HW 3
li.p: Due Tuesday Oct 17
A truck that hauls water is capable of carrying a maximum of 3000. Water weighs 8.3454, and the plastic tank on the truck that holds water weighs 66.

Suppose you want to find the maximum number of gallons of water the truck can carry. Write an equation to model this scenario. There is no need to solve it,, but if you would like to, you are welcome to. If you are unsure of how to solve it, you should not try to yet.

li.title: Written HW 4
li.p: Due Tuesday Oct 24

The number of students enrolled in math courses at Portland Community College has grown over the years. The formulas: M\amp=0.36x+4.2\amp W\amp=0.48x+4.9 describe the numbers (of thousands) of men and women enrolled in math courses at PCC x years after 2005. Give a simplified formula for the total number of thousands of students at PCC taking math classes x years after 2005 by simplifying (0.36x+4.2)+(0.48x+4.9).

Do not simply jump from this expression to the answer. As we did once or twice in class, use the associative properties, commutative properties, and distributive property one step at a time to simplify this. Probably your first two lines should look like: \amp(0.36x+4.2)+(0.48x+4.9) \amp=0.36x+(4.2+0.48x)+4.9\amp\amp\text{by the associative property of addition} \amp\ldots .

li.title: Written HW 5
li.p: Due Tuesday Oct 31

Massage Heaven and Massage You are competitors. Massage Heaven has 9900 registered customers, but it is losing approximately 200 registered customers every month. Massage You has 3900 registered customers, and it gets approximately 300 newly registered customers every month. How many months would it take Massage Heaven to catch up with Massage You in the number of registered customers?

Be sure to define any variables you use, set up an algebraic equation, and then carefully work through the steps in a way that makes it easy for someone else to understand everything you thought and did.

li.title: Written HW 6
li.p: Due Tuesday Nov 14

To calculate a student's final grade in MTH 60, we use the formula G=0.045A+0.1W+0.1H+0.065C+0.23E_1+0.23E_2+0.23E_3 where G is the final grade average, A is the attendance average, W is the average, H is the written homework average, C is the textbook contribution score, and E_1,E_2,E_3 are the three exam scores. All of these averages and scores are out of 100.
Solve this equation for E_3.

For a particular student, the final attendance average is 90, the final average is 96, the final written homework average is 75, the textbook contribution score is 92, the exam 1 score is 65, and the exam 2 score is 74. Use the formula you solved to find:
the final exam score needed to bring the overall final grade average to 70
the final exam score needed to bring the overall final grade average to 80
the final exam score needed to bring the overall final grade average to 90
